ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

APPOINTMENT OF CONSTITUTIONAL EXPERTS TO ADVISE ON
CONSTITUTIONAL ASPECTS OF CLOSER RELATIONSHIP WITH
FEDERATION


    1. Mr David Marshall asked the Prime Minister whether Government will consider the appointment of Constitutional experts of international stature to advise the Government and the people of Singapore, through their representatives in the Assembly, on Constitutional aspects of the proposed closer relationship with the Federation of Malaya.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, five eminent constitutional jurists from Britain, India, Pakistan, Australia and Canada constituted the Commission which drafted the present Constitution of the Federation of Malaya. Several other constitutional lawyers helped in the work. It is hoped that some of these lawyers, who are already familiar with the Constitution, may be able to advise the Government on how to enshrine the new provisions

Column: 500

in the Constitution of the Federation of Malaysia.

    The State Advocate-General is already in correspondence with constitutional lawyers of considerable experience and standing who will have to help in spelling out the amendments consequent upon the heads of agreement reached between the Singapore and the Federation Governments. He is also offering a contract to a parliamentary draftsman who will be able to assist him in the work of drafting. If any Member of the Assembly desires clarification on any constitutional matter consequent upon merger between Singapore and Malaya, the Government will put these questions to the State Advocate-General who can give his advice, if necessary, after taking further opinion from constitutional experts elsewhere.

    Mr David Marshall (Anson): May I ask the Prime Minister what is the procedure proposed - writing directly to the Prime Minister or to the State Advocate-General for that purpose with reference to queries from Assemblymen?

    The Prime Minister: Sir, I will be happy to receive any letters from any Members of the Assembly.

    Mr David Marshall: I am much obliged.

SUB-BRANCHES OF LIFE INSURANCE COMPANIES IN
SINGAPORE
(Number closed down and action taken to protect policy-holders)


    2. Mr Ong Chang Sam asked the Minister for Finance how many sub-branches of life insurance companies in Singapore whose head offices are in the Federation of Malaya have closed down, or have been closed down, from 1st December, 1961, to the latest convenient date; and what action he has taken or proposes to take to protect the policyholders insured by these sub-branches.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the following Federation life insurance companies have registered branches in Singapore. I give both the names of

the companies and the date of registration:

    From this list, Members will note that nearly all these branches have commenced business in Singapore in the latter half of last year, in addition, the following insurance companies have recently been incorporated in Singapore although they have also been doing business in the Federation. These companies with headquarters in Singapore are:

    In addition, there may be other unregistered branches of companies doing business here. The Police are on the trail of some of these with a view to prosecution.

    As regards the general problem, the Singapore Government has been for some time in close touch with the Federation Government with a view to introducing adequate control over insurance companies. Legislation has already been passed in the Federation which empowers the Government to close down insurance companies which conduct their business in an improper way. Further legislation is in hand to empower the

Column: 502

Government to wind up these companies and distribute their assets to policyholders. I understand that such legislation will shortly be introduced in the Federation Parliament on a Certificate of Urgency. The Singapore Government intends to take similar action here, combining the two pieces of legislation into one. I have been assured that in the distribution of the assests of these companies to policy-holders, there will be no discrimination between policy-holders in Singapore and those in the Federation whether the company is incorporated in one territory or the other. I am informed, however, that the mismanagement of several of these companies has been so bad that it is unlikely that policy-holders will get more than a portion of the money they have put in. Fortunately, however, most of these companies have only recently commenced business before the Federation Government took action to deal with them. The probable loss of money which policy-holders may suffer has therefore been limited by the prompt action taken by the Federation Government. These insurance com panics receive payments of small sums of money, usually between $3 and $12 per month per policy-holder. A $3 monthly contribution would entitle the policy-holder to a sum of $400 on death or in ten years' time.

    Since most of the companies were incorporated in the Federation, the initiative in taking action to wind up these companies rests with the Federation Government. As I mentioned before, policy-holders in Singapore will be treated on the same basis as policy-holders in the Federation.

    In the near future, the two Governments intend to introduce full and comprehensive legislation over the insurance business and there will be appointed a Commissioner of Insurance which will take charge of a pan-Malayan department with authority to enforce the law in both territories. The present set of insurance laws which the two Governments are proposing is only the first step in the control of the insurance business. It is intended specifically to combat the mushroom insurance companies which had been springing up in recent months.

    Mr Ong Chang Sam (Choa Chu Kang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I an very glad to know that the Minister for Finance has declared to this I louse that in the near future the Government will be introducing legislation to protect the policy-holders. But as far as I know, at the present moment, there are many insurance company agents who have wound up their business. I want to ask the Minister for Finance whether at the present moment legal action can he taken against these agents to recover the money paid by the policy-holders.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, I did say in my answer to the question that the police are on the trail of some of these companies - those who have not complied with the law as regards registration of companies and the deposit of a sum of money with the Attorney-General. Of course, when the Ordinance is passed here, we can un a sep further and wind up these companies and distribute whatever assets remain to policy-holders.

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): Under our insurance laws, before an insurance company can do business, certain sums of money have to be deposited. Could the Minister assure the House that these branches of Federation companies which are carrying on or had been carrying on business here have had those sums deposited under the law?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: If these companies have deposited monies with the Federation Government, they are not required to make a similar deposit in Singapore. But where they have not, then they must do so. But the trouble with these companies is not that they do not make these deposits of money. Several of them have deposited these sums of money and they are still in serious trouble. The reason is that they do not conduct insurance business in the proper actuarial way. Let me give some examples. When you lake out a policy, you need not take cut one on year own life. You can take out a policy on somebody else's life. Quite often, the policy-holder will say, "This man may croak very soon." So he takes out a policy on this man, and if the man dies after nine

Column: 504

months, he gets the capital sum. There is no proper medical examination which reputable insurance companies carry out as a matter of course. The whole system under which these so-called insurance companies work is rather similar to the Chinese benevolent societies whereby you set aside certain small sums of money -

    Mr Rajah: Mutual aid.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Yes, and then you get certain benefits in the event of death either of yourself or of certain persons that you can nominate. But whereas mutual aid societies are run on a non-profit making basis by people who get together, it is suspected that many of these companies are nothing more than downright swindles. In fact, the accounts f same of these companies have been examined by the Federation Government end they show a most intolerable state of affairs. Fortunately they do not appear to have sold very expensive policies; also most of them have not been operating for a very long time. So although damage has been done, the damage is somewhat restricted.

    Mr David Marshall: Has the Minister considered some means of advising the better intentioned of these companies who are seeking to meet the needs of the poor for insurance, in order to assist them to a stable financial policy?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: It is very difficult for me to meet the point raised by the Member for Anson, because the full facts of this whole business are not known. Only a number of cases have been brought to light, either by complaints raised by policy-holders who want ta claim their capital assured and have not been able to do so, or complaints by agents, and preliminary examinations into the accounts of a few of these. If there are genuine honest companies which attempt to meet a social need and are run in a proper way, then I think when we come across such eases we shall see what can be done. But my view is that the manner in which all those businesses have been conducted shows, firstly, that there has been an inadequate understanding of the actual

Column: 505

principles on which any insurance business should be run, and secondly, the financiers behind some of these businesses are persons of doubtful repute. That, is the thing that has been troubling the people.

    Mr Ong Chang Sam(In Mandarin): if the policy-holders are not able to trace the insurance agents, will the Minister for Finance find it necessary to set up a commission to ensure that complaints can be received from such policy-holders as to the amount they have paid up, and as to how they can recover their paid-up money?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: As far as the policy-holders of the companies are concerned, and as far as these policy-holders go, I think the only remedy is for the companies to be liquidated and for the assets to be distributed in fair proportions among these policy-holders.

    As regards what the policy-holders should do in future, once the Insurance Bill is passed then everyone can rest assured that the premium rates in relation to benefits which insurance companies charge are both fair to those taking out policies and sound from the point of view of the insurance company itself. I do not think it is necessary to set up a Committee to advise policy-holders because, in this instance, I think many if not most of them have had their fingers burnt.

    Mr Rajah: Sir, could the Minister assure the House whether, in view of the fact that people of doubtful character are operating these insurance companies, he would take adequate steps under the existing laws to see that no more of these companies or agents from the Federation come to Singapore to operate in future as they have done previously?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I have already said in my answer that we shall past laws similar to those now obtaining in the Federation and which the Federation will soon pass. This will provide effective control on such companies.

YAH LIN YAH KER
(Permission to stage play)


    3. Mr Ong Chang Sam asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether he is aware that permission to stage the play Yah Lin Yah Ker was refused, and whether he will give the reasons for the refusal.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, permission to stage the play Yah Lin Yah Ker or Serenade in the Coconut Plantation was refused on the grounds that the play encourages students to become involved in labour strikes, and in the present industrial situation its performance will be contrary to the interests of the State and of the students who should be concentrating on their studies.

    Mr Ong Chang Sam(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, as far as I know, application for this play to be staged was made on 5th September last year to the Minister for Home Affairs. It was only on 13th December that the application was refused, and no reason was given for such refusal.

    From what the Minister has said just now, this play, as a matter of fact, is not the type that is described by the Minister.

    Mr Speaker: Order. What the Member can do is to give certain facts leading up to a supplementary question. Let us have a supplementary question; there can be no debate.

    Mr Ong Chang Sam(In Mandarin): I would like to ask the Minister for Home Affairs this: does he mean that when students and workers are together, they are involved in industrial action?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: The answer is no.

CHINESE SECONDARY IV STUDENTS ADMITTED TO OR REFUSED
ADMISSION TO UPPER SECONDARY I CLASSES
(Statistics)


    5. Mr Ong Chang Sam asked the Minister for Education how many students were in the Chinese Secondary Four classes as at 31St December, 1961, in all schools; how many have been admitted to Upper Secondary I classes in 1962; and how many have been refused admission and the reasons for non-admission.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, there were 2,932 students in Chinese Secondary IV classes as at 31st December, 1961, and as the admission to Upper Secondary I classes in the Chinese medium is by way of the School Secondary IV Examination it is necessary to state, first of all, that the number who have passed the 1961 School Secondary IV Examination was 2,348. Of these, 2,080 students (or 88 per cent) were admitted to Upper Secondary I classes as at 13th January, 1962. No one who has passed the School Secondary IV Examination has been refused admission, although a small number - 62 - were unable to get places in schools of their own choice but have been found places in other schools by the Ministry of Education. However, Mr Speaker, Sir, it has been brought to my notice only this morning that eight students who passed the Adult Education Board's internal Secondary IV examination, after having been accepted for registration by the Chung Cheng High School for Upper Secondary I classes, were asked to leave on 20th instant, on the grounds that they were not from regular schools, although they had already made their schools uniforms, bought books, and paid fees for the first term. It is regretted that the Principal of Chung Cheng High School should have asked these students to leave without first consulting with the Ministry. In these circumstances, I wish to state that the eight students concerned will be given places in Upper Secondary I classes

that are being conducted by the Adult Education Board at the River Valley Government Secondary School.

WEST IRIAN


    Order read for resumption of debate on Question (18th January, 1962),

    "That this House, taking cognizance of the heroic struggle of the Indonesian people to liberate Irian Barat from colonial rule, expresses admiration for the determination and courage of the Indonesian people and expresses full sympathy with their hopes and aspirations, and calls upon the people of Singapore to give their wholehearted support to our neighbours and friends, the people of Indonesia, in their just and legitimate struggle against colonial domination.". - (Dr Lee Siew Choh).

    Question again proposed.

3.01 p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Inche Yaacob Bin Mohamed)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, before the adjournment last Friday, I spoke about the positiveness of the Government's attitude in its support of the Indonesian people's struggle to wrest West Irian from the Dutch. Before that, Mr Speaker, I was greatly impressed by the appeal of the Member for Thomson which asked Members of this Assembly, especially the Government, to debate seriously the motion before the House. He accused the Government of allegedly sneering or ridiculing this motion. The Member also suggested that the Government is belittling the struggle of the Indonesian people. I strongly refute this allegation. We, the Government, have constantly given our wholehearted support to their struggle. We view with grave concern the events taking place in the neighbouring country of Indonesia. We are fully conscious of the fact that developments in Indonesia have repercussions or reactions in our country. For that reason, we, the Government, have not the slightest intention to disregard this motion or not to give the respect that it deserves. However, our actual stand on this matter has been twisted by Members of the Barisan Sosialis. The Member for Thomson has accused us of having insulted and affronted the Indonesian people in their struggle to eradicate colonialism from West Irian.

Column: 510



    Mr Speaker, we view this accusation with concern because the object of the speeches made by the Barisan Sosialis is to damage the good relationship between the Government of Indonesia and the Government of Singapore. This good relationship already existed, more particularly so during the time of the present Government. He also charged that the Government had intimidated the people who put up placards or posters in support of the Indonesian struggle against Dutch colonialism. But, Mr Speaker, in addition to what has already been said by my colleague, the Member for Ulu Pandan, about the work of putting up posters late at night, it is also a fact that they were put up in great numbers bearing the symbol of the Barisan Sosialis. So they were putting up these posters in order to make known the Barisan Sosialis to the public.

    Mr Speaker, our stand wholeheartedly in support of the struggle of the Indonesian people is not false. It is positive. We support the struggle in all consciousness. We have no ulterior motive. However, what we are surprised at, Mr Speaker, are the tactics and the attitude of the mover of this motion. His attitude, like the proverbial Malay saying, is just like a cock crowing. This means that people who only talk and find fault merely make empty noises, and they fail to realise their own mistakes. Mr Speaker, this attitude of the Barisan Sosialis astounds us. When we ridicule them, we do not direct it at Indonesia. We direct our ridicule or insult at the Members of the Barisan Sosialis.

    Mr Speaker, let us recollect some of the past events and of the people who live in the Malay Archipelago, or Temasek. Temasek is an old name for Singapore. It has been willed by God that people who are sincere and honest should have been oppressed by the Western colonialists who, because of their lust and greed, succeeded in dividing the people. The Western colonialists shared the spoils of the Malay Archipelago amongst the Dutch, the British and the Americans. Thus the Malay Archipelago was divided into

Column: 511

three spheres until the end of the Second World War. Mr Speaker, God has also willed that the people should rise in order to free themselves from the yoke of colonialism. The Indonesian people woke up. They declared their independence in spite of the sacrifices which they had to make to achieve their independence. Finally, the independence of the Indonesian people was recognised by the world, including the Dutch. It was, however, decided that the problem of West Irian should be resolved through negotiations. American colonialism in the Philippines was uneasy. Finally, the Americans also gave independence to the Filipinos. But American colonialism preferred to make an orderly retreat to being forced to retreat. Likewise, British colonialism had no alternative but to give independence to the Malayan nationalists. They did it before they were ejected forcibly. For that reason, Mr Speaker, it is our duty, as one nation in the Malay Archipelago, to be united in our efforts to wipe out colonialism. Since the Philippines has thrown away the yoke of colonialism and the Indonesian people have broken away from colonialism, we will not only wipe out British colonialism here but will also wipe out colonialism in the Borneo territories.

    Mr Speaker, the era of colonialism in Asia will definitely end. British colonialism is on its way out. The Dutch colonialists are adopting a stone-headed attitude. They forget Asian nationalism. They are stubborn in wanting to hold on to West Irian. For that reason, Mr Speaker, we give them this warning. Although the cow is a weak animal, we get milk from it. It is also used to pull carts. Although it may not have horns, one day it will rise and use all its energies to free itself. This is the spirit and the determination of the people of the Malay Archipelago in South-East Asia.

    Mr Speaker, the people of Malaya, especially in Malacca, were under the rule of the Dutch. I still remember, when I was in school, a history book entitled "Hikayat Abdullah". It was related in this book how tyrannical the Dutch were

Column: 512

towards her subject people. The Dutch colonialists will pay heavily for this tyrannical attitude. Their inhuman action took the form of torturing and burying people alive. Some were tied and beaten to death. Some were hung to death. There were many other inhuman atrocities committed by the Dutch. This is an excerpt from history to show the atrocities of Dutch colonialism, especially in Malacca. The same atrocities were committed in Indonesia. For instance, the name of Westerling will remain in our memory, for he killed thousands of innocent people in the Island of Celebes. Therefore, when we talk about colonialism in whatever form it is, what is fresh in our mind are the atrocities which the colonialists committed on their subject peoples. For this reason, if there are among us those who are satisfied or who are complacent with the power given to us by the colonial powers, they are only the puppets of the colonial power. Only stooges are prepared to tolerate such a state of affairs. This clearly shows the attitude of the Barisan Sosialis when they moved this motion of merger and Malaysia. The Barisan Sosialis opposed merger and Malaysia. I think Mr Speaker himself knows the position as well as I do.

    Mr Speaker, we recollect, since the West Irian issue could not be resolved through negotiations at the conference table, how the Dutch then tried to offer self-government to West Irian by changing the name of West Irian to Papua, and suggesting a flag for Papua, thereby using the Papuans as their stooges or puppets to support their action. It would appear, in the words of the Minister for Culture, that if there were a Barisan Sosialis in West Irian, they would accept the Dutch plan, i.e., to form a self-government under the auspices of the colonial Dutch. This is clear from their stand that there should be complete self-government for Singapore, rather than that Singapore should merge with the Federation. Is this the type of people who wish to support the struggle of the Indonesian people for the return of West Irian to the Indonesian Government? Mr

Column: 513

Speaker, if we support the struggle of the Indonesian people, it is not because our support is superfluous, or because we are anti-colonialists, or to gain publicity and make political capital out of this in order to get political support. People who at all times say, "I love you," are not genuine in their love. It is false and has a sinister motive. Such people make only empty promises. They produce only noises, but no results. In order to achieve peace and happiness, we say frankly and openly that our stand is that we love peace and justice. So we warn the Dutch to resolve this dispute peacefully, surrender West Irian to the Indonesian people, and leave Irian Barat in an orderly manner. All this is for the sake of world peace and harmony.

    We are wholeheartedly behind the people of Indonesia. The spirit and determination of the Indonesian people are the same as ours. We support wholeheartedly and we give our sympathy to the struggle of the Indonesian people. Our support is behind the Indonesian people who were once the subject people of the Dutch, because we are against colonialism in any kind or form. This anti-colonial attitude is embedded in our soul and in the people of Asia. For that reason, Mr Speaker, we are making our appeal in the interest of peace. If we hit a snake, we are going to make sure it is dead and that the stick which we use to hit it is undamaged. As long as there is hope for negotiations, we must make use of it. I also appeal to Members of the Barisan Sosialis, to go back to the main road if they are lost in a cul-de-sac. I ask them not to use this international issue to make political capital and gain followers in the country to support their Party. We realise that our people are comprised mainly of anti-colonial people. But, as has been mentioned by the Member for Geylang Serai, although they can see the germs across the sea, they cannot see the elephant in front of their nose. So I wish to appeal to the Barisan Sosialis not to dig holes because they will be buried in

Column: 514

them. They should not always behave like a cock. As I have said just now, the cock crows, but there is nothing in it.

    Mr Speaker, I say that if we have been laughing at the motion which is being debated now, it is not because we wish to insult or show disrespect to the Indonesian people in their struggle. But what we are amused at are the tactics and behaviour of Members of the Barisan Sosialis when they speak on this motion. Once again, Mr Speaker, I wish to say that we wholeheartedly support the Indonesian people in their struggle to wrest West Irian from the Dutch colonialists. We have not lost hope that this dispute may be settled peacefully. This is our stand. Once again I deny categorically the accusation of the Barisan Sosialis that we are treating this motion lightly.

3.25 p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Chan Chee Seng): Mr Speaker, I fully support the intention of the motion, but I am not the same as the Barisan Sosialis who use filthy mud to thrown before the people's eyes.

    Mr Speaker, today I would only like to make a point on this motion. We have heard the Member for Thomson say that the P.A.P. has no sympathy with the Indonesian struggle to regain West Irian, because a number of people have been detained for questioning by the police for sticking up posters.

    An hon. Member: That is true.

    Mr Chan Chee Seng: The same complain was made at a rally organised by the Barisan Sosialis in support of West Irian. I am surprised that the Member for Thomson should have repeated this allegation after the correction made in the Government statement issued on 13th January. I would like to quote to you, Mr Speaker, Sir, the Straits Times of 13th January - this statement was issued by the Ministry of Culture:

    `A Ministry of Culture statement today said the attempt "to mislead the listeners" could only be deliberate, as the speakers well knew why their followers had been detained for questioning by the police.
